summary: experts from the US Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Swedish National Veterinary Institute (SVA), the Swedish Civil Contingencies Agency (MSB) and the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center spoke to a group gathered for a workshop. participants included 40 representatives from academic institutions and nongovernment institutions in the US and Europe. they came from a range of US government agencies, including the Department of Agriculture (USDA), the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the Department FMD is endemic in Asia, Africa, the Middle East, and parts of south America. the virus that causes the disease is relatively hardy, can survive transport, and is highly contagious among cloven-hooved animals. the program continues to work on developing vaccines for other foreign animal diseases, other novel vaccine platforms, and improved vaccines. aniBioThreat aims to improve the eu's capacity to counter deliberate biological threats to agriculture by raising awareness and implementing prevention policies and practices. the results of the aniBioThreat project were published in a supplement to the journal Biosecurity and Bioterrorism in september 2013. the special issue contains 29 articles about bioterrorism threats to animals, feed, and food. the USDA oversees more than 30 of the 60-plus select agents and toxins. Agricultural Defense Branch in DHS's Science and Technology Directorate (S&T) has taken steps to reduce FMD virus vulnerabilities starting with an FMD vaccine program that was initiated in 2005. the program continues to work on developing vaccines for other foreign animal diseases, other novel vaccine platforms, and improved vaccines. a staff of 170 people contributed to aniBioThreat from the law enforcement and animal and public health communities. the project led to improved interoperability, updated contingency plans for animal threats (including animal botulism and anthrax), training events, formal exercises, a course for practitioners on early warning and strategic analysis. multidisciplinary approaches are needed at the local, national, and global levels to prevent and mitigate crises at the interface between humans, animals, and the environment. veterinary, human, and environmental health disciplines have in large part remained separate in their work and professional training.
